<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of pipe_reader:
```c
static ssize_t
pipe_reader (void *cls,
             uint64_t pos,
             char *buf,
             size_t max)
{
  struct MHD_Response *response = cls;
  ssize_t n;

  (void) pos;

#ifndef _WIN32
  if (SSIZE_MAX < max)
    max = SSIZE_MAX;
  n = read (response->fd,
            buf,
            (MHD_SCKT_SEND_SIZE_) max);
#else  /* _WIN32 */
  if (UINT_MAX < max)
    max = INT_MAX;
  n = read (response->fd,
            buf,
            (unsigned int) max);
#endif /* _WIN32 */

  if (0 == n)
    return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM;
  if (n < 0)
    return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR;
  return n;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the parameter 'max' is assigned to inside the function (in both the non-WIN32 and _WIN32 branches). Assigning to a function parameter is exactly what MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 forbids. Other parts of the function do not modify parameters and therefore do not need investigation for this rule: (void) pos does not modify 'pos' (it merely marks it as unused); the assignment 'struct MHD_Response *response = cls;' reads 'cls' but does not modify the parameter itself (casting/assigning to a local pointer is allowed); passing 'buf' and the pointer 'response->fd' to read() may result in modification of the objects they point to (which is permitted), but the pointer parameters themselves are not altered; the casts applied in the read() calls do not modify parameters. Therefore only the shown assignments to 'max' require investigation under Rule 17.8.
